Comprehensive Pig Weight Data Processing Pipeline

Source: R/clean_weight_get.R
clean_weight_get.Rd

Advanced weight data cleaning and validation system for porcine growth analysis, integrating multiple quality control checks and statistical validation steps.

clean_weight_get(
  data,
  my_break,
  range_offset = 0.5,
  min_days = 35,
  min_records = 20,
  min_na_perc = 0.3,
  w_threshold = 0.5,
  maxit = 1000,
  entry_weight_limit = 65,
  exit_weight_limit = 85,
  max_weight_limit = 15,
  days_extend = 30,
  step = 1,
  degree = 2,
  print_details = FALSE,
  quiet = FALSE
)

Arguments

data

Input data.table containing processed pig weight records

  • Must contain columns:

    • responder (unique identifier)

    • location (measurement location)

    • date (date of measurement)

    • seq_days (sequence days)

    • seq_in_location (sequence in location)

    • seq_in_day (sequence in day)

    • weight (weight measurements in grams)

  • Requires output from preprocess_data()

  • Supports parallel processing via data.table optimizations

my_break

Target weight range specification

  • Format: Numeric vector of length 2 [lower, upper]

  • Units: Kilograms (kg)

  • Constraint: my_break[1] < my_break[2]

  • Example: c(30, 120) for 30-120kg range

range_offset

Weight range extension buffer

  • Purpose: Extends target range for boundary cases

  • Units: Kilograms (kg)

  • Default: 0.5

  • Constraint: Must be positive value

min_days

Minimum observation period requirement

  • Purpose: Filters short-term measurements

  • Units: Days

  • Default: 35

min_records

Minimum data points per responder

  • Purpose: Ensures sufficient data density

  • Default: 20

min_na_perc

Maximum allowable missing data ratio

  • Purpose: Controls data completeness

  • Format: Proportion between 0-1

  • Default: 0.3 (30% maximum NA)

w_threshold

Robust regression outlier cutoff

  • Purpose: Identifies statistical outliers

  • Default: 0.5

  • Technical: Weight threshold for MASS::rlm weights

  • Constraint: Typically 0.5-1.0

maxit

Maximum iterations for robust regression

  • Purpose: Controls model convergence

  • Default: 1000

entry_weight_limit

Maximum allowable entry weight

  • Purpose: Filters over-conditioned starters

  • Units: Kilograms (kg)

  • Default: 65

  • Constraint: Must be < exit_weight_limit

exit_weight_limit

Minimum required exit weight

  • Purpose: Ensures market readiness

  • Units: Kilograms (kg)

  • Default: 85

  • Constraint: Must be > entry_weight_limit

max_weight_limit

Physiological weight ceiling

  • Purpose: Removes biologically implausible values

  • Units: Kilograms (kg)

  • Default: 150

  • Constraint: Should exceed exit_weight_limit

days_extend

Prediction window extension

  • Purpose: Forecast period for growth modeling

  • Units: Days

  • Default: 30

  • Constraint: Must be >= 0

step

Prediction interval granularity

  • Purpose: Controls forecast resolution

  • Units: Days

  • Default: 1

degree

Polynomial regression complexity

  • Purpose: Determines growth curve flexibility

  • Default: 2 (quadratic)

  • Constraint: 1 <= degree <= 3

print_details

Diagnostic output control

  • Purpose: Enables detailed process reporting

  • Default: FALSE

  • Note: Overridden by quiet = TRUE

quiet

Logical. If TRUE, suppresses messages and warnings. Default: FALSE.

Value

Structured list containing:

  • cleaned_data:

    • Validated data.table with outlier flags

    • Contains columns:

      • responder, location, date

      • seq_days, seq_in_location, seq_in_day

      • weight, rlm_predict, rlm_outliers

  • deleted_responders:

    • Character vector of removed IDs

    • Categorized removal reasons

  • validation_metrics:

    • Pre/post-cleaning responder counts

    • Outlier percentage analysis

    • Weight limit compliance stats

Details

Multi-Stage Processing Pipeline:

  1. Input Validation

    • Data structure verification

    • Parameter sanity checks

    • Column existence validation

  2. Data Cleansing

    • Unit conversion (kg to g)

    • Invalid responder filtering

    • Temporal consistency checks

    • Missing data thresholding

  3. Statistical Validation

    • Robust regression modeling (MASS::rlm)

    • Outlier detection and removal

    • Growth curve analysis

  4. Biological Plausibility Checks

    • Entry/exit weight validation

    • Physiological limit enforcement

    • Growth trajectory analysis

Quality Control Metrics:

  • Responder-level completeness analysis

  • Temporal coverage assessment

  • Measurement consistency scoring

  • Outlier impact quantification

See also

  • preprocess_data() For input data preparation

Examples

result_nedap <- preprocess_data(data = mintyr::nedap, station_type = "nedap", quiet = TRUE)
clean_weight <- clean_weight_get(result_nedap, my_break = c(30,120), quiet = TRUE)
head(clean_weight)
#> Key: <responder>
#>    responder location       date seq_in_location seq_days seq_in_day weight
#>       <char>   <char>     <Date>           <int>    <int>      <int>  <int>

#> 2:     13913      101 2024-02-20               1        2          1  23500
#> 3:     13913      101 2024-02-20               2        2          2  31000
#> 4:     13913      101 2024-02-20               3        2          3  23500
#> 5:     13913      101 2024-02-20               4        2          4  24000
#> 6:     13913      101 2024-02-20               6        2          6  28500

#> 2:    23212.70        FALSE
#> 3:    23212.70         TRUE
#> 4:    23212.70        FALSE

#> 6:    23212.70        FALSE
